"'''In the Jailhouse Now'''" is an American [[Novelty song|novelty]] blues song originally found in [[vaudeville]] performances from the early 20th century,<ref name="Neal-131">[http://www.iupress.indiana.edu/catalog/product_info.php?products_id=96228 The Songs of Jimmie Rodgers], p. 131</ref> usually credited to [[Jimmie Rodgers (country singer)|Jimmie Rodgers]]. The song's first two verses trace the exploits of Ramblin’ Bob, who cheats at cards and gets caught, while the final verse tells about taking a girl named Susie out on the town and winding up in jail together.<ref name="Neal-119">[http://www.iupress.indiana.edu/catalog/product_info.php?products_id=96228 The Songs of Jimmie Rodgers], p. 119</ref>
== Jimmie Rodgers recording == Rodgers version of "In the Jailhouse Now" was recorded February 15, 1928, in [[Camden, New Jersey|Camden]], [[New Jersey]], and features Rodgers on vocals and guitar, with [[Ellsworth T. Cozzens]] playing [[banjo]].<ref name="Porterfield-137">[http://www.upress.state.ms.us/books/877 ''Jimmie Rodgers: The Life and Times of America's Blue Yodeler''], pp. 137-138</ref> Rodgers included his famous [[yodel]] throughout the song. He recorded a [[sequel]] titled "In the Jailhouse Now—No. 2" in [[Hollywood]], [[California]], in 1930, which follows the misadventures of a man named Campbell.<ref name="Porterfield-258">[http://www.upress.state.ms.us/books/877 ''Jimmie Rodgers: The Life and Times of America's Blue Yodeler''], p. 258</ref>
== Recording and copyright history == {{Infobox song | name = In the Jailhouse Now | cover = | alt = | type = single | artist = [[Webb Pierce]] | album = | B-side = I'm Gonna Fall Out of Love with You | released = December 1954 | format = [[7" single|7"]] | recorded = December 3, 1954 | studio = | venue = | genre = [[Country music|Country]] | length = | label = [[Decca Records|Decca]] <small>9-29391</small> | writer = Jimmie Rodgers and Elsie McWilliams | producer = [[Paul Cohen (record producer)|Paul Cohen]] | prev_title = [[More and More (Webb Pierce song)|More and More]] | prev_year = 1954 | next_title = [[I Don't Care (Webb Pierce song)|I Don't Care]] | next_year = 1955 }}
The song has been covered many times, most frequently with Jimmie Rodgers’ version. Artists who have sung it include [[Tommy Duncan]], [[Webb Pierce]], [[Pink Anderson]], [[Johnny Cash]], [[Jim Jackson (musician)|Jim Jackson]], [[Leon Russell]], [[Mother McCree's Uptown Jug Champions]] (featuring [[Jerry Garcia]]), [[Merle Haggard]], [[Doc Watson]], [[Prism (band)|Prism]], [[Suzy Bogguss]] (with [[Chet Atkins]]), and [[Tim Blake Nelson]] with [[The Soggy Bottom Boys]] in the film and soundtrack for ''[[O Brother, Where Art Thou?]]''. It was also one of the first songs learned by a teenage [[Joan Baez]]. The song shows up under different titles including "He's in the Jailhouse Now," and some versions use the line "She's in the graveyard now" in the chorus.<ref name="Neal-141">[http://www.iupress.indiana.edu/catalog/product_info.php?products_id=96228 ''The Songs of Jimmie Rodgers''], p. 141,163</ref>
Prior to 1930, several different versions of it were recorded and copyrighted. The earliest is Davis and Stafford's 1915 version, which has verses about a man named Campbell cheating at a card game and a corrupt election.<ref name="Neal-132">[http://www.iupress.indiana.edu/catalog/product_info.php?products_id=96228 ''The Songs of Jimmie Rodgers''], p. 132</ref> In 1924, [[Whistler's Jug Band]] from [[Louisville, Kentucky|Louisville]], [[Kentucky]], recorded it under the title "[[Jail House Blues]]," which was the same title as a famous blues tune by [[Bessie Smith]] but was, in fact, the same song as "In the Jailhouse Now".<ref name="Neal-135">[http://www.iupress.indiana.edu/catalog/product_info.php?products_id=96228 ''The Songs of Jimmie Rodgers''], p. 135</ref>
In 1927, [[Earl McDonald]]'s [[Original Louisville Jug Band]] made another recording of the song.<ref name="Neal-139">[http://www.iupress.indiana.edu/catalog/product_info.php?products_id=96228 ''The Songs of Jimmie Rodgers''], p. 139</ref> Two African-American bluesmen also recorded the song prior to Rodgers: [[Blind Blake]] (in 1927), and [[Jim Jackson (musician)|Jim Jackson]] (in January 1928). Jackson also copyrighted the song before Rodgers.<ref name="Neal-156">[http://www.iupress.indiana.edu/catalog/product_info.php?products_id=96228 ''The Songs of Jimmie Rodgers''], p. 156</ref> Finally, in 1930, the Memphis Sheiks (a pseudonym for the [[Memphis Jug Band]]) recorded it in a version that scholars have often claimed, [[albeit]] mistakenly, was a cover of Jimmie Rodgers.<ref name="Neal-149">[http://www.iupress.indiana.edu/catalog/product_info.php?products_id=96228 ''The Songs of Jimmie Rodgers''], p. 149-150</ref> The version of the melody and lyrics that they used, is clearly derived from the Louisville Jug Band performances, not Rodgers. On some of the Memphis Sheiks' records, an African-American vaudeville performer named [[Bert Murphy]] is given credit for writing the song.<ref name="Neal-291">[http://www.iupress.indiana.edu/catalog/product_info.php?products_id=96228 The Songs of Jimmie Rodgers], p. 291-292</ref>
Shortly after Rodgers recorded the song, three additional versions appeared that were decidedly not covers of Rodgers. [[Boyd Senter]] and his [[Senterpedes]] did a [[jazz]] version in 1929 for [[Victor Records]] (issued on #22010, and later reissued on [[Bluebird Records]] #5545);<ref>Abrams, Steven and Settlemier, Tyrone [http://www.78discography.com/vic22000.html Online Discographical Project: Victor 22000 - 22500] Retrieved September 14, 2011</ref> [[Gene Kardos]] and His Orchestra also did a jazz version in 1932 for Victor; and [[Billy Mitchell (jazz musician)|Billy Mitchell]] did a [[stride piano]] and [[shouter]] version of it in 1936 for the Bluebird label.<ref name="Neal-165">[http://www.iupress.indiana.edu/catalog/product_info.php?products_id=96228 ''The Songs of Jimmie Rodgers''], pp. 165-168</ref>
After Rodgers, the best-known version of the song was by [[Webb Pierce]], who had a No. 1 country hit with the song in 1955.<ref name="Neal-171">[http://www.iupress.indiana.edu/catalog/product_info.php?products_id=96228 ''The Songs of Jimmie Rodgers''], p. 171</ref> Pierce's version spent No. 1 on the ''Billboard'' country chart for 21 weeks, becoming the third song in the chart's history to spend as long on the chart; previously, [[Eddy Arnold]] ("[[I'll Hold You in My Heart (Till I Can Hold You in My Arms)]]," 1947) and [[Hank Snow]] ("[[I'm Moving On (Hank Snow song)|I'm Movin' On]]," 1950) achieved the feat. For 58 years, those three songs held the longevity record for most weeks at No. 1 with 21 weeks, with only a handful of songs coming within a month of matching the record into the early 1960s. Finally, on August 10, 2013, "[[Cruise (song)|Cruise]]" by [[Florida Georgia Line]] surpassed Pierce's "In the Jailhouse Now" for most weeks at No. 1 when it spent its 22nd week at No. 1.
When [[Johnny Cash]] recorded the song in 1962, he used lyrics that are different from Jimmie Rodgers' versions which Cash learned from the African-American jug band musicians in Memphis.<ref name="Neal-177">[http://www.iupress.indiana.edu/catalog/product_info.php?products_id=96228 ''The Songs of Jimmie Rodgers''], pp. 177-180</ref> In spite of this, most writers claim that Cash was covering Jimmie Rodgers' song, which further obscures that the song originated with African-American performers and was kept alive in a vaudeville and jug band tradition for many decades.<ref name="Neal-182">[http://www.iupress.indiana.edu/catalog/product_info.php?products_id=96228 ''The Songs of Jimmie Rodgers''], p. 182</ref>
The song regained popularity years later when [[Sonny James]] recorded a live version during a 1976 concert at [[Tennessee State Prison]]. James' version included backing by the Tennessee State Prison Band, and peaked at No. 15 on the Hot Country Singles chart in 1977.
The Jimmie Rodgers version was sung by Gene Autry in his 1941 movie "Back in the Saddle."
In ''[[O Brother, Where Art Thou?]]'', "Delmar" ([[Tim Blake Nelson]]) sings a rendition, with "Pete" ([[John Turturro]]) yodeling between the verses, prior to the Soggy Bottom Boys' main number, "[[Man of Constant Sorrow]]". The other "Soggy Bottom Boys" songs are lip-synched, but Tim Blake Nelson sings his own vocals on this song, while Turturro's yodeling is actually performed by Pat Enright of the [[Nashville Bluegrass Band]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Rowell |first1=Erica |title=The Brothers Grim: The Films of Ethan and Joel Coen |publisher=Rowman & Littlefield |year=2007 |page=276 n.59 |isbn=978-0810858503 }} [https://books.google.com/books?id=pWSw_p2pYvwC&lpg=PA276&ots=IO5WgFcRwR&dq=in%20the%20jailhouse%20now%20john%20turturro&pg=PA276#v=onepage&q=in%20the%20jailhouse%20now%20john%20turturro&f=false Excerpts available] at [[Google Books]].</ref>
In 1979, the song was done in a blackface performance in the musical ''[[One Mo' Time]]'' by [[Vernel Bagneris]].<ref name="Neal-187">[http://www.iupress.indiana.edu/catalog/product_info.php?products_id=96228 ''The Songs of Jimmie Rodgers''], p. 187</ref> The musical was revived on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] in 2002. The version of the song used in the show was the same as that recorded by the Louisville Jug Bands in the 1920s.<ref name="Neal-188">[http://www.iupress.indiana.edu/catalog/product_info.php?products_id=96228 ''The Songs of Jimmie Rodgers''], p. 188</ref>
[[Brad Paisley]] used the chorus for the end of "Mr. Policeman," a song on his 2007 album ''[[5th Gear (album)|5th Gear]]''. New lyrics were written to provide an ending to the song's story.

{{Infobox institute | name = Institute for Slavic Studies of the Russian Academy of Sciences ([[Russian language|Russian]]: Институт славяноведения РАН) | image = | image_upright = | alt = | caption = | latin_name = | motto = | founder = [[:ru:Федеральное агентство научных организаций|Federal Agency of Scientific Institutions]] | established = 1947 | mission = | focus = [[Slavic studies]] | president = {{Interlanguage link multi|Konstantin Nikiforov|ru|3=Никифоров, Константин Владимирович|vertical-align=sup}} | ceo = | chairman = | head_label = | head = | faculty = | adjunct_faculty = | staff = | key_people = | budget = | endowment = | debt = | num_members = | subsidiaries = | owner = | non-profit_slogan = | former_name = Institute for Slavic and Balcan Studies of the Academy of Sciences of the USSR | location = | city = [[Moscow]] | state = | province = | country = Russia | coor = | address = 119991 Moscow, [[Leninsky Avenue, Moscow|Leninsky Prospekt]] 32A | website = http://www.inslav.ru/ | dissolved = | footnotes = }}
The '''Institute for Slavic Studies of the Russian Academy of Sciences''' ([[Russian language|Russian]]: Институт славяноведения РАН) is an integral part of the Historical and Philological Studies Department of the [[Russian Academy of Sciences]].<ref>It is a traditional affiliation of the Institute. Currently, as a result of the [[Russian Academy of Sciences#Dissolution of the Russian Academy of Sciences|dissolution of the Russian Academy of Sciences]], the Institute is formally subordinate to the Federal Agency of Scientific Institutions.</ref> It is a unique Russian academic institution focused on comprehensive [[Slavic studies|studies of Slavic history, culture, literature, and languages]]. The Institute carries on the traditions of Russian Slavic scholars that have evolved over the last two centuries.
== History == The Institute was founded in 1947 as the Institute for Slavic and Balcan Studies of the Academy of Sciences of the USSR. Since 1997, the Institute has its current name. Amongst the researchers of the Institute were [[Academician]]s of the [[Russian Academy of Sciences|RAS]]: [[Yulian Bromley]], [[:ru:Державин, Николай Севастьянович|Nikolay Derzhavin]], [[Boris Grekov]], [[:ru:Литаврин, Геннадий Григорьевич|Gennady Litavrin]], [[:ru:Марков, Дмитрий Фёдорович|Dmitry Markov]], [[Leonid Milov]], [[:ru:Обнорский, Сергей Петрович|Sergey Obnorsky]], [[:ru:Пичета, Владимир Иванович|Vladimir Picheta]], [[:ru:Писарев, Юрий Алексеевич|Yury Pisarev]], [[Mikhail Tikhomirov]], [[:ru:Толстой, Никита Ильич|Nikita Tolstoy]], [[Vladimir Toporov]], and [[Oleg Trubachyov]]; [[Academician#Corresponding Member|Corresponding Members]] of the [[Russian Academy of Sciences|RAS]]: [[:ru:Николаева, Татьяна Михайловна|Tatiana Nikolaeva]], [[:ru:Третьяков, Пётр Николаевич|Petr Tretyakov]], [[:ru:Удальцова, Зинаида Владимировна|Zinaida Udaltsova]], and [[:ru:Волков, Владимир Константинович|Vladimir Volkov]]. Currently, there are [[Academician]]s of the [[Russian Academy of Sciences|RAS]]: [[Vladimir Dybo]], [[Vyacheslav Ivanov (philologist)|Vyacheslav Ivanov]], and [[Andrey Zaliznyak|Andrey A. Zaliznyak]]; Foreign Member of the [[Serbian Academy of Sciences and Arts]] [[:ru:Турилов, Анатолий Аркадьевич|Anatolij A. Turilov]]; and [[Academician#Corresponding Member|Corresponding Members]] of the [[Russian Academy of Sciences|RAS]]: [[:ru:Гиппиус, Алексей Алексеевич|Aleksey Gippius]] and [[:ru:Флоря, Борис Николаевич|Boris Floria]].
The principal lines of research at the Institute are as follows:
* Historico-cultural and ethnic studies of the Slavs and their neighbors; ethnogenesis of the Slavs; * Research into and maintenance of cultural traditions; Slavic booklore; archival heritage of Slavic scholars; history of Slavic studies; * Tradition and modernization; social and national movements; foreign affairs and military conflicts in Central, Eastern, and South Eastern Europe; * Reception of Russian culture by Slavic cultures and reception of Slavic cultures by Russia; * Comparative study of Slavic culture, literature, and folklore; * Typological, contrastive, and comparative study of Ancient and Modern Slavic, Balkan, and Baltic languages and dialects; ethnolinguistics.
== Academic journals, yearbooks, and periodicals == The Institute for Slavic Studies publishes several [[academic journal]]s and periodicals:
'''''Slavianovedenie'''''
''Slavianovedenie'' ([[Russian language|Russian]]: [[:ru:Славяноведение (журнал)|''Славяноведение'']], ISSN 0132-1366) is an [[academic journal]] published six times a year since 1965 (before 1992, ''Sovetskoe Slavianovedenie''). Issues of the journal since 1965 till 2009 are available free on the website of the Institute.<ref>http://www.inslav.ru/izdaniya/slavianovedenie</ref>
'''''Slověne'''''
[[Slověne. International Journal of Slavic Studies|''Slověne = Словѣне. International Journal of Slavic Studies'']] (pISSN 2304-0785, eISSN 2305-6754) is a biannual [[Peer review|peer-reviewed]] [[open-access]] [[academic journal]] since 2012.<ref>http://slovene.ru/</ref>
'''''Slavic Almanac''''' ([[Russian language|Russian]]: ''Славянский альманах'', ISSN 2073-5731) is published since 1997.<ref>http://www.inslav.ru/component/content/article/1636-slavic-almanac</ref>
'''''Slavic World in the Third Millennium''''' ([[Russian language|Russian]]: ''Славянский мир в третьем тысячелетии'') is a yearbook published since 2006.<ref>http://www.inslav.ru/component/content/article/1853-slavic-world-in-the-third-millennium</ref>
'''''Archaeographic Yearbook''''' ([[Russian language|Russian]]: [[:ru: Археографический ежегодник|''Археографический ежегодник'']]) has been published since 1957 by the [[Archaeographic Commission]].
== Other yearbooks and periodicals == * ''The Slavic Linguistic Atlas'' ([[Russian language|Russian]]: [[:ru:Общеславянский лингвистический атлас|''Общеславянский лингвистический атлас'']]) * ''Khazarian Almanac'' ([[Russian language|Russian]]: ''Хазарский альманах'') * ''The Library of the Institute for Slavic Studies'' ([[Russian language|Russian]]: ''Библиотека Института славяноведения РАН'') * ''Belarus and Ukraine: History and Culture'' ([[Russian language|Russian]]: ''Белоруссия и Украина: история и культура'') * ''Studies in Slavic Dialectology'' ([[Russian language|Russian]]: ''Исследования по славянской диалектологии'')

'''John Cage Day''' was the name given to several events held during 2012, to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the birth of the composer [[John Cage]].
These events included John Cage Day at the [[Museum of Modern Art]], New York, held on August 9, 2012,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.moma.org/visit/calendar/events/15360 |title=Modern Poets: John Cage Day |publisher=MoMA |date=2012-08-09 |accessdate=2012-09-25}}</ref> John Cage Day at [[The Proms]] in the [[Royal Albert Hall]], London, on August 17, 2012,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/proms/whats-on/2012/august-17/14218 |title=Proms - Prom 47 Cage Centenary Celebration 2012 |publisher=BBC |date=1970-01-01 |accessdate=2012-09-25}}</ref> and John Cage Day at [[Elder Conservatorium|Elder Hall]], [[University of Adelaide]], Australia, coinciding with Cage's birthday on September 5, 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.realtimearts.net/article/110/10790 |title=Magazine - issue 110 - stephen whittington: musical renewal |publisher=RealTime Arts |date=2012-09-05 |accessdate=2012-09-25}}</ref> The organizer of the latter event, composer and performer [[Stephen Whittington]], has proposed that September 5 annually celebrated globally as John Cage Day.<ref>{{cite web|last=Lloyd |first=Tim |url=http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/news/south-australia/john-cage-day-celebrated-in-adelaide-with-free-concert-at-elder-hall-on-wednesday/story-e6frea83-1226463487740 |title=John Cage Day celebrated in Adelaide with free concert at Elder Hall on Wednesday |publisher=adelaidenow |date=2012-09-02 |accessdate=2012-09-25}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{one source|date=March 2011}} [[File:John-O-Hart-1892--Irish-Pedigrees.png|thumb|right|300px|A sketch of John O'Hart first published in Irish pedigrees; or, The origin and stem of the Irish nation (1892), by John O'Hart, - Volume: 1.]] '''John O'Hart''' (1824–1902) was an [[Ireland|Irish]] [[genealogy|genealogist]]. He was born in Crossmolina, [[County Mayo|Co. Mayo]], [[Ireland]]. A committed [[Roman Catholic]], O'Hart originally planned to become Catholic priest but instead spent 2 years as a police officer. He was an [[Associate in Arts]] at the [[Queen's University of Belfast]]. He worked at the Commissioners of National Education during the years of the [[Great Irish Famine]]. He worked as a genealogist and took an interest in [[Irish history]]. He was an [[Irish nationalist]]. He died in 1902 in [[Clontarf (Ireland)|Clontarf]] near [[Dublin]], at the age of 78. O'Hart's 800-page ''The Irish and Anglo-Irish landed gentry'' (Dublin 1884) was reprinted in 1969, with an introduction by [[Edward McLysaght|Edward MacLysaght]], the first [[Chief Herald of Ireland]]. Another work, ''Irish pedigrees; or, The origin and stem of the Irish nation'', first published in 1876, has come out in several subsequent editions. To complete his genealogies he used the writings of [[Cú Choigcríche Ó Cléirigh]], [[Duald Mac Firbis]] and O'Farrell, along with the [[Annals of the Four Masters]], for the medieval pedigrees. He used the works of [[Bernard Burke]], John Collins and others to extend his genealogies past the 17th century. ==Stem of the Irish nation== In his ''Irish Pedigrees'', O'Hart presents the legendary origins of the Irish people, from the Biblical Adam and Eve through the kings of ancient [[Ireland]]. Irish tradition holds that every Irish person is descended from the king [[Milesius]] who emigrated from [[Spain]] in approximately 1700 BC, according to the [[Annals of the Four Masters]]. O'Hart started each of his genealogies with [[Adam (Bible)|Adam]] recording Milesius as his 36th descendant. From the start;
(1) [[Adam (Bible)|Adam]], his son
(2) [[Seth]], his son
(3) [[Enos (Bible)|Enos]], his son
(4) [[Kenan|Cainan]], his son
(5) [[Mahalalel|Mahalaleel]], his son
(6) [[Jared (Biblical figure)|Jared]], his son
(7) [[Enoch (ancestor of Noah)|Enoch]], his son
(8) [[Methuselah]], his son
(9) [[Lamech (father of Noah)|Lamech]], his son
(10) [[Noah]], his son
(11) [[Japhet]], his son
(12) [[Magog (Bible)|Magog]], his son
(13) [[Baath mac Magog|Baoth]] "to whom [[Scythia]] came has his lot," his son
(14) [[Phoeniusa Farsaidh]] ([[Fenius Farsa]]) King of Scythia, his son
(15) [[Niul]], his son
(16) [[Gaodhal]] (Gathelus), his son
(17) [[Asruth]], his son
(18) [[Sruth]] (who fled [[Egypt]] to [[Creta]]), his son
(19) [[Heber Scut]] (returned to Scythia), his son
(20) [[Beouman]], King of Scythia, his son
(21) [[Ogaman]] King of Scythia, his son
(22) [[King Tait|Tait]] King of Scythia, his son
(23) [[Agnon (Irish legend)|Agnon]] (who fled Scythia by sea with the majority of his people), his son
(24) [[Lamhfionn]] (who led his people to [[Götaland|Gothia]] or [[Getulia]], where [[Carthage]] was afterwards built), his son
(25) [[Heber Glunfionn]] King of Gothia, his son
(26) [[Agnan Fionn]] King of Gothia, his son
(27) [[Febric Glas]] King of Gothia, his son
(28) [[Nenuall]] King of Gothia, his son
(29) [[Nuadhad]] King of Gothia, his son
(30) [[Alladh]] King of Gothia, his son
(31) [[Arcadh]] King of Gothia, his son
(32) [[King Deag|Deag]] King of Gothia, his son
(33) [[King Brath|Brath]] King of Gothia (who left Gothia with a large band of his people and settled in [[Galicia (Spain)|Galicia]], [[Spain]]), his son
(34) [[Breoghan]] King of Galicia, [[Andalusia]], [[Murcia]], [[Kingdom of Castile|Castile]], and [[Portugal]], his son
(35) [[Bile (Irish legend)|Bile]] King of Galicia, Andalusia, Murcia, Castile, and Portugal, and his son
(36) [[Galamh]] (also known as [[Milesius]] of Spain) King of Galicia, Andalusia, Murcia, Castile, and Portugal. According to O'Hart's account, [[Milesius]] had four sons, [[Éber Finn|Heber]], Ir, [[Érimón|Heremon]], and [[Amergin Glúingel|Amergin]], who were involved, along with their uncle Ithe, in the invasion of ancient [[Ireland]]; [[Milesius]], himself, had died during the planning. Because Amergin died during the invasion, he died without issue. It is from the four other invaders--[[Éber Finn|Heber]], [[Ir (Irish mythology)|Ir]], [[Heremon]], and [[Ithe]]—that the Irish are alleged to descend. These, according to O'Hart, are the four lines from which all true Irish descend. [[Conn of the Hundred Battles]] was a descendant of Erimon, and [[Brian Boru]] was descended from both Heber and Conn. ==Sources== Irish pedigrees; or, The origin and stem of the Irish nation (1892), by John O'Hart, is available in 2 volumes free on the [[Internet Archive]]. :''Irish pedigrees; or, The origin and stem of the Irish nation (1892), by John O'Hart, - Volume: 1'' :''{{URL|https://archive.org/details/irishpedigreesor_01ohar}}'' :''Irish pedigrees; or, The origin and stem of the Irish nation (1892), by John O'Hart, - Volume: 2'' :''{{URL|https://archive.org/details/irishpedigreesor02ohar}}'' Another book by John O'Hart is also available free on the Internet Archive. :''The Irish landed gentry when Cromwell came to Ireland (1887), by John O'Hart;'' :''{{URL|https://archive.org/details/irishlandedgentr00ohar}}'' ==External links== *[http://www.geoghegan.org/clan/ancient.html Geoghegan family genealogy as compiled by John O'Hart] {{Authority control}} {{Irish genealogy}} {{Celtic mythology (Mythological)}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ohart, John}} [[Category:1824 births]] [[Category:1902 deaths]] [[Category:Celtic studies scholars]] [[Category:Irish genealogists]] [[Category:Irish historians]] [[Category:People from County Mayo]]

[[Canaanites|Canaanite city-states]] |wars=[[Battle of Kadesh]] |designer= |design_date= |manufacturer= |unit_cost= |production_date= |number= |variants= |weight= |length= avg. {{convert|50|-|60|cm|in|abbr=on}} |part_length= |width= |height= |diameter= |crew= |blade_type=Curved |hilt_type= |sheath_type= |head_type= |haft_type= }}{{Hiero |''ḫpš'' ('leg')|Aa1:Q3-N37:F23-F51([[Coffin Texts]])||align=right|era=egypt}} '''''Khopesh''''' (''{{lang|egy-Latn|ḫpš}}''; also vocalized '''khepesh''') is an Egyptian [[sickle]]-sword that evolved from battle axes.Hamblin, 2006. ''Warfare in the Ancient Near East,'' pp. 66–71.{{cite book|last=Wise|first=Terence|title=Ancient Armies of the Middle East|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tCLoNSNX1JwC&pg=PA23|year=1981|publisher=Osprey Publishing|isbn=978-0-85045-384-3|pages=23–25}} A typical khopesh is 50–60 cm (20–24 inches) in length, though smaller examples do also exist. The blunted edge of the weapon's tip also served as an effective bludgeon, as well as a hook. These weapons changed from bronze to iron in the New Kingdom period.{{cite book|last=Howard|first=Dan|title=Bronze Age Military Equipment|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=diOx0cfHegEC&pg=PA34|year=2011|publisher=Casemate Publishers|isbn=978-1-84884-293-9|pages=31–34}} The earliest known depiction of a khopesh is from the [[Stele of Vultures]], depicting [[Eannatum|King Eannatum]] of [[Lagash]] wielding the weapon; this would date the khopesh to at least 2500 BC.{{cite book|author=Mike Loades|title=Swords and Swordsmen|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yLU-bwAACAAJ|year=2010|publisher=Pen & Sword Military|isbn=978-1-84884-133-8|pages=1–21}} The word 'khopesh' may have derived from 'leg', as in 'leg of beef', because of their similarity in shape. The hieroglyph for ''ḫpš'' ('leg') is found as early as during the time of the [[Coffin Texts]] (the [[First Intermediate Period]]).Coffin Texts: CT V, 9c, B1C The blade is only sharpened on the outside portion of the curved end. The khopesh evolved from the [[Epsilon axe|epsilon]] or similar crescent-shaped axes that were used in warfare. The khopesh went out of use around 1300 BC. However, in the 196 BC [[Rosetta Stone]] it is referenced as the "sword" [[determinative]] in a [[quadrate (hieroglyph block)|hieroglyphic block]], with the spelled letters of [[sieve (hieroglyph)|kh]], [[stool-or-mat (hieroglyph)|p]], and [[pool-lake-basin (hieroglyph)|sh]] to say: {{quote|Shall be set up a statue..., the [[cross-ndj (hieroglyph)|Avenger]] of Baq-t-(Egypt), the interpretation whereof is '[[Ptolemy V|Ptolemy]], the [[branch (hieroglyph)|strong one]] of [[km (hieroglyph)|Kam-t]]'-(Egypt), and a statue of the god of the city, giving to him a sword royal of [[branch (hieroglyph)|victory]], ...Budge, 1989, (1929). ''The Rosetta Stone,'' p. 155–156. ('''Rosetta line 6''')}} Various pharaohs are depicted with a khopesh, and some have been found in royal graves, such as the two examples found with [[Tutankhamun]]. Although some examples are clearly sharpened, many examples have dull edges that apparently were never intended to be sharp. It may therefore be possible that some khopeshes found in high status graves were ceremonial variants. ==See also== {{Portal|Ancient Near East}} * [[Falcata]] * [[Falx]] * [[Harpe]] * [[Kopis]] * [[Makraka]] * [[Shotel]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==Bibliography== * Budge, 1989, (1929). ''Warfare in the Ancient Near East,'' [[William J. [[US State Department|State Department]], Division for Southeast Asian Affairs |alma_mater = [[Harvard University]] |doctoral_advisor = |academic_advisors = |doctoral_students = |notable_students = [[G. William Skinner]] |known_for = Applied Anthropology
Founded [[Cornell Southeast Asia Program]]
Founding member of the Society for Applied Anthropology |author_abbrev_bot = |author_abbrev_zoo = |influences = |influenced = |awards = [[Bronislaw Malinowski Award]]
[[Guggenheim Fellowship]]
[[Fulbright Program|Fulbright Fellowship]]
[[National Endowment for the Humanities]] Fellowship |religion = |signature = |signature_alt = |footnotes = }} '''Lauriston Sharp''' (March 24, 1907 – December 31, 1993) was a [[Goldwin Smith]] Professor of [[Anthropology]] and [[Asian Studies]] at [[Cornell University]]. He was the first person appointed in anthropology at the university, and he created its [[Cornell Southeast Asia Program|Southeast Asia Program]], research centers in Asia and North and South America, a multidisciplinary faculty and strong language program. He was a founding member of the [[Society for Applied Anthropology]] and a founding trustee of the [[Asia Society]]. == Early life and education == Sharp was born in 1907 in [[Madison, Wisconsin]], where he grew up. His father was a professor of [[philosophy]] at the [[University of Wisconsin–Madison]]. Sharp attended this same institution, studying for a Bachelor of Arts (BA). While majoring in philosophy, Sharp went with friends [[Clyde Kluckhohn]] and John J. Hanks on summer treks to [[archaeological]] sites on the Kaiparowitz Plateau in [[Arizona]] and [[Utah]]. These expeditions sparked his interest in the concrete, culturally informed [[anthropologist]]'s perspective on human nature, in contrast to the more abstract, universalizing view of a philosopher. After graduating with his BA in 1929, Sharp identified anthropology and [[Southeast Asian studies]] as his career focus. He encountered [[Berber mythology|Berber]] culture while on an expedition to [[Algeria]] in 1930 with the Beloit-Logan Museum. Sharp moved to [[Austria]] to study Southeast Asian Ethnology under [[Robert Heine-Geldern]], receiving the Certificate in Anthropology from the [[University of Vienna]] in 1931. He enrolled in the PhD program at [[Harvard University]] in 1932 and completed his thesis in 1937, after two years of fieldwork studying [[Australian Aborigines]]. ==Marriage and family== Sharp married Ruth Burdick, and they had a family. She contributed to the Bennington-Cornell Thailand Project with expertise in anthropology and ceramics. They had a son named Alexander and a daughter named Suki. == Academic career == Professor Sharp began teaching at Cornell in 1936; he was the university's first appointment in anthropology. He remained devoted to Cornell, creating and directing programs, and teaching at and remaining connected with the university for 56 years. He remained active as the Goldwin Smith Professor Emeritus, even after his formal retirement in 1973. During an appointment at the [[US State Department|State Department]] in 1945 and 1946, Sharp was an assistant division chief for Southeast Asian affairs. Upon returning to Cornell, Sharp oversaw the expansion of the anthropology program, making it a leading center for graduate training and research. His vision of anthropology was to emphasize an applied orientation and focus on area studies. He established Cornell research centers in [[South Asia|South]] and [[Southeast Asia]] and [[North America|North]] and [[South America]]. In 1947, Sharp began the Cornell-Thailand Project, a ground-breaking initiative to collate baseline data in a comprehensive study of a farming village (''Bang Chan'') on the outskirts of [[Bangkok]]. Sharp also founded and was the first director between 1950 and 1960 of Cornell's Southeast Asia Program, for which he recruited a multi-disciplinary faculty, developed a strong language program and started what become the foremost library resource on South East Asia. Sharp provided for scholars from the areas studied to receive training in such programs, in addition to hundreds of Western scholars. He chaired the Cornell Faculty Committee, which in 1961 saw the creation of the university's Center for International Studies. Aside from realizing Sharp's longtime dream of Southeast Asian research, the Thailand project also marked the start of his collaboration with Lucien Hanks and Jane Hanks of [[Bennington College]]. This continued in the Bennington-Cornell Project started in 1963, which entailed a broad regional survey of the upland and lowland peoples of northern Thailand. His wife, Ruth Burdick Sharp, contributed her acquired expertise in anthropology and ceramics to this project. Despite health problems which made field research difficult after retirement, Sharp maintained his activity at Cornell and abroad. He worked with his research documents on Thailand as well as on Australian Aborigines. == Publications and organizations == Sharp's professional career spanned wide geographical areas. As a scholar-researcher, he studied indigenous cultures on four continents. Several of his publications became classics in their fields: ''Steel Axes for Stone-Age Australians'' (1952), ''People Without Politics'' (1958), and ''Cultural Continuities and Discontinuities in Southeast Asia'' (1962). A number of his coauthored works exhibited his multidisciplinary research and interest in culture change, such as ''Siamese Rice Village'' (1953) and ''Bang Chan: Social History of A Rural Community in Thailand'' (1978). Sharp had a reputation for passion in passing on his experiences to future generations. Sharp was president of the [[Association for Asian Studies]] from 1961 to 1962. He was a founding member of the [[Society for Applied Anthropology]] and a founding trustee of the [[Asia Society]]. He served on the governing boards of the [[American Anthropological Association]] and the Siam Society. He won Guggenheim, Fulbright, and National Endowment for the Humanities fellowships. Upon retiring, he was presented with a two-volume ''[[festschrift]]'', one celebrating his contributions to studies of cultural change and applied anthropology, the other recognizing his contributions to [[Thai studies]]. He died at the age of 86 at his [[Ithaca, New York]] home on December 31, 1993. ==Major works== *''Steel Axes for Stone-Age Australians'' (1952) *''People Without Politics'' (1958) *''Cultural Continuities and Discontinuities in Southeast Asia'' (1962) Co-authored: *''Siamese Rice Village'' (1953) *''Bang Chan: Social History of A Rural Community in Thailand'' (1978){{cite journal | last1= Sharp | first1 = Lauriston | authorlink1 = Lauriston Sharp |coauthors= |first2= Lucien M. |last2= Hanks |date=Winter 1983 |title= Bang Chan: Social History of a Rural Community in Thailand |journal= [[Ethnohistory (journal)|Ethnohistory]] |volume= 30 |issue= 1 |pages=35–36 |editor= Brian L. Foster, ed. |publisher= Duke University Press |doi= 10.2307/481501 |jstor= 481501 |laysource= |laysummary= |laydate= |quote= }} ==Legacy and honors== *The Lauriston Sharp Prize is awarded each year to the graduate student who has contributed most outstandingly to both scholarship and the community life of the Cornell Southeast Asia Program.https://ecommons.cornell.edu/bitstream/handle/1813/18163/Sharp_R_Lauriston_1993.pdf;sequence=2 *1989, the [[Bronislaw Malinowski Award]] of the Society of Applied Anthropology. ==See also== * [[Bronislaw Malinowski Award]] * [[Lauriston Sharp Prize]] ==Publications on-line== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110609163142/http://www.soc.iastate.edu/Soc130/Readings/Unit%20I/Steel%20Axes%20for%20Stone-Age%20Australians.pdf Sharp, Lauriston (1952) ''Steel Axes for Stone-Age Australians''] ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==References== *{{cite journal| first= A. Thomas |last=Kirsc|date=November 1994 |title=Obituary: Lauriston Sharp (1907-1993) |journal=[[Journal of Asian Studies]] |volume=53 |issue=4 |pages=1358–1359. }} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110716094938/http://www.sfaa.net/malinowski/monograph/Chapter19.pdf Weaver, Thomas (2002) 'Lauriston Sharp: Innovator of Applied Anthropology Programs" Chapter 19, Malinowski Award Papers. Society for Applied Anthropology]Accessed 10 October 2009 * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100528214521/http://www.mnsu.edu/emuseum/information/biography/pqrst/sharp_lauriston.html Lauriston Sharp biographical piece at Minnesota State University's e-Museum] Accessed 10 October 2009 {{AAS Presidents}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sharp, Lauriston}} [[Category:1907 births]] [[Category:1993 deaths]] [[Category:University of Wisconsin–Madison alumni]] [[Category:American anthropologists]] [[Category:Cornell University faculty]] [[Category:Guggenheim Fellows]] [[Category:Harvard University alumni]] [[Category:Presidents of the Association for Asian Studies]]

The '''Legal Education Eligibility Test''' ('''LEET''') is an examination which will be administered by the [[Korea Institute of Curriculum and Evaluation]] (KICE), intended to provide [[law school]]s in the [[Republic of Korea]] an evaluation metric to measure reading and reasoning skills required for successful [[legal education]]. The exam is similar in goal and content with the [[Public Service Aptitude Test]] (PSAT) administered as a part of the Korean civil service exams. The [[Law School Admission Test]] of the [[United States]] serves as the model for the test.[http://english.moe.go.kr/main.jsp?idx=070101&brd_no=30&cp=1&pageSize=10&srchSel=&srchVal=&brd_mainno=519&mode=v Welcome to the Ministry of Education & Human Resources Development] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070321095030/http://english.moe.go.kr/main.jsp?idx=070101 |date=2007-03-21 }} ==Administration== KICE will administer the first LEET in 2018. KICE administers the [[Law School Admission Test|LSAT]] once a year in August. The current bar exam will be in place for a few years. == Test composition == The test currently has three 90-120 minute sections. Two are multiple choice sections and one section is a writing section. === Reading Comprehension === The section contains several Korean reading passages and questions pertaining to the main idea and structure. === Logical Reasoning === The section, like that of the [[Law School Admission Test|LSAT]] contains questions that test the logical reasoning skills. === Writing === The format is not finalized yet. == Preparation == Since the test is not yet administered, no preparation guide or course is available yet. The KICE is expected to release more information and sample exam later this year. No legal knowledge is required or tested in the LEET. == Scoring == Not finalized yet. == Latest Development == On January 24 2008, the first model test will be held in Seoul. The model test is for research purpose and the score is not official. The first actual test will be held in August 2008. ==References== {{reflist}} == See also == *[[Legal Education]] *[[Korean Bar Association]] *[[Korea Institute of Curriculum and Evaluation]] *[[Standardized testing]] ==External links== * [http://www.leet.or.kr Official Website] * [https://www.koreaherald.co.kr/SITE/data/html_dir/2007/07/05/200707050011.asp Korea to adopt U.S. style law schools in 2009]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}

{{For|the fencing organization|Brotherhood of St. Mark}} {{Infobox comedian | name = The Marx Brothers | image = [[File:Marx Brothers 1931.jpg|250px]] | image_size = | alt = | caption = Four of the five Marx Brothers in 1931 (top to bottom: [[Chico Marx|Chico]], [[Harpo Marx|Harpo]], [[Groucho Marx|Groucho]] and [[Zeppo Marx|Zeppo]]) | medium = Film, [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]], [[vaudeville]] | nationality = American | active = 1905–1949 | genre = [[Word play]], [[slapstick]], [[musical comedy]], [[deadpan]] | subject = | influences = | influenced = | alma_mater = | notable_work = | website = | footnotes = | past_members = ''Principal:''

[[Gummo Marx]]
[[Zeppo Marx]] | monuments = | module = }} The '''Marx Brothers''' were an American family comedy act that was successful in [[vaudeville]], on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]], and in [[motion pictures]] from 1905 to 1949. Five of the Marx Brothers' thirteen feature films were selected by the [[American Film Institute]] (AFI) as among the [[AFI's 100 Years...100 Laughs|top 100 comedy films]], with two of them (''[[Duck Soup (1933 film)|Duck Soup]]'' and ''[[A Night at the Opera (film)|A Night at the Opera]]'') in the top twelve. They are widely considered by critics, scholars, and fans to be among the greatest and most influential comedians of the 20th century. The brothers were included in [[AFI's 100 Years...100 Stars]] list of the 25 greatest male stars of Classic Hollywood cinema, the only performers to be inducted collectively. The group is almost universally known today by their [[stage name]]s: [[Chico Marx|Chico]], [[Harpo Marx|Harpo]], [[Groucho Marx|Groucho]], [[Gummo Marx|Gummo]], and [[Zeppo Marx|Zeppo]]. There was a 6th brother, the first born, named Manfred (Mannie), who died aged 7 months; Zeppo was given the middle name Manfred in his memory. The core of the act was the three elder brothers: Chico, Harpo, and Groucho, each of whom developed a highly distinctive stage persona. After the group essentially disbanded in 1950, Groucho went on to begin a successful second career in [[television]], while Harpo and Chico appeared less prominently. The two younger brothers, Gummo and Zeppo, never developed their stage characters to the same extent as the elder three. They each left the act to pursue business careers at which they were successful, and for a time ran a large theatrical agency through which they represented their brothers and others. Gummo was not in any of the movies; Zeppo appeared in the first five films in relatively straight (non-comedic) roles. The performing lives of the brothers owed much to their mother [[Minnie Marx]], who acted as their manager until her death in 1929. ==Brothers' names, family background, and lifetimes== [[File:Early marx brothers with parents.jpg|thumb|right|The only known photo of the entire Marx family, c. 1915. From left: [[Groucho Marx|Groucho]], [[Gummo Marx|Gummo]], [[Minnie Marx|Minnie (mother)]], [[Zeppo Marx|Zeppo]], [[Sam Marx|Sam (father)]], [[Chico Marx|Chico]], and [[Harpo Marx|Harpo]].]] [[File:Groucho und harpo.jpg|thumb|right|Julius Henry Marx (Groucho) on the left and Adolph Marx (Harpo) on the right holding a rat terrier dog, c. 1906]] The Marx Brothers were born in [[New York City]], the sons of [[Jewish]] immigrants from [[Germany]] and [[France]]. Their mother [[Minnie Marx|Miene "Minnie" Schoenberg]] (professionally known as Minnie Palmer, later the brothers' manager) was from [[Dornum]] in [[East Frisia]], and their father [[Sam Marx|Samuel]] ("Sam"; born Simon) Marx was a native of [[Alsace]] and worked as a tailor.{{cite web|url=http://judaisme.sdv.fr/perso/marxbr/geneal.htm|title=La famille paternelle des Marx Brothers|website=Judaisme.sdv.fr|accessdate=21 September 2018}}{{cite news|title=Mrs. Minnie Marx. Mother of Four Marx Brothers, Musical Comedy Stars, Dies.|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1929/09/16/95997162.html#95997162.html?pageNumber=21&_suid=147094807936009446111808468656|accessdate=11 August 2016|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=September 16, 1929|page=27}} (His name was changed to Samuel Marx, and he was nicknamed "Frenchy".){{cite news|title=Samuel Marx, Father of Four Marx Brothers of Stage and Screen Fame|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=May 12, 1933|page=17|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1933/05/12/105134141.html#105134141.html?pageNumber=17&_suid=147094749463206243483555181057|accessdate=2016-08-11}} The family lived in the poor [[Yorkville, Manhattan|Yorkville]] section of New York City's [[Upper East Side]], centered in the Irish, German and Italian quarters.
