[[File:Vardzia, Georgia.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Five monks still live in this mountain. Every morning at seven they ring the bell in the high arch. ]] '''Vardzia''' ({{lang-ka|ვარძია}}) is a [[cave monastery]] site in southern [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]], [[Rock cut architecture|excavated]] from the slopes of the Erusheti Mountain on the left bank of the [[Kura (Caspian Sea)|Kura River]], thirty kilometres from [[Aspindza]]. The main period of construction was the second half of the twelfth century. The caves stretch along the cliff for some five hundred meters and in up to nineteen tiers. The Church of the [[Dormition of the Theotokos|Dormition]], dating to the 1180s during the [[golden age]] of [[Tamar of Georgia|Tamar]] and [[Shota Rustaveli|Rustaveli]], has an important series of [[Mural|wall paintings]]. The site was largely abandoned after the [[History of Georgia (country)#Ottoman and Persian domination|Ottoman takeover]] in the sixteenth century. Now part of a state heritage reserve, the extended area of Vardzia-[[Khertvisi]] has been submitted for future inscription on the [[UNESCO]] [[World Heritage List]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.parliament.ge/pages/archive_ge/art/mural/georghy/meskheti.html |title=About Meskheti |publisher=[[Parliament of Georgia]] |accessdate=1 May 2012}}</ref><ref name="reserve">{{cite web |url=http://heritagesites.ge/?lang=eng&page=305 |title=Vardzia Historical-Architectural Museum-Reserve |publisher=[[National Agency for Cultural Heritage Preservation of Georgia]] |accessdate=1 May 2012}}</ref><ref name="UNESCO">{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/5236/ |title=Vardzia-Khertvisi |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=1 May 2012}}</ref><ref name="NACH">{{cite web |url=http://heritagesites.ge/?lang=eng&page=313 |title=Vardzia Monastery complex |publisher=[[National Agency for Cultural Heritage Preservation of Georgia]] |accessdate=4 May 2012}}</ref>
==History== [[File:Queen Tamar - Vardzia fresco.jpg|thumb|160px|left|[[Tamar of Georgia|Tamar]] in the Church of the Dormition, with a model of the church; an [[Aetiology|aetiological myth]] has the young Tamar, when out hunting with [[George III of Georgia|Giorgi]], lost in the caves; when called for, she replied "I am here, uncle" ({{lang-ka|აქ ვარ ძია}}) "ac var dzia", giving the site its name<ref name="GG"/>]] [[Georgian Soviet Socialist Republic|Soviet-era]] excavations have shown that the area of Vardzia was inhabited during the [[Bronze Age]] and indicated the reach of [[Trialeti culture]]. Cave settlements such as [[Uplistsikhe]] are known along the [[Kura (Caspian Sea)|Kura River]] from at least the fifth century BC, while [[rock cut architecture]] in the context of [[Christianity in Georgia (country)|Georgian Christianity]] is known from [[Zedazeni Monastery|Zedazeni]] and Garedzhi from the sixth century AD, and more locally from [[Vanis Kvabebi]], Cholta and Margastani from the eighth century.<ref name="GG">{{cite book |title=Ancient Monuments of Georgia: Vardzia |author=Gaprindashvili, Ghivi |year=1975 |publisher=Aurora Art Publishers, Leningrad |language=English, Russian, Georgian |isbn=978-1-135-68320-7 |pages=7-25}}</ref> Four distinct building phases have been identified at Vardzia: the first during the reign of [[George III of Georgia|Giorgi III]] (1156–1184), when the site was laid out and the first cave dwellings excavated; the second between his death and the marriage of his successor [[Tamar of Georgia|Tamar]] in 1186, when the Church of the Dormition was carved out and decorated; the third from that date until the [[Battle of Basian]] c.1203, during which time many more dwellings as well as the defences, water supply, and irrigation network were constructed; while the fourth was a period of partial rebuilding after heavy damage in the earthquake of 1283.<ref name="GG"/>
A number of documentary sources supplement the knowledge derived from the site's physical fabric. The collection of chronicles known as the ''[[The Georgian Chronicles|History of Georgia]]'' refers to Tamar erecting a church to house the [[icon]] of the Virgin of Vardzia after receiving divine help in her campaigns, before transferring the monastery from Upper or Zeda Vardzia. Tamar is said to have departed from Vardzia during her [[Tamar of Georgia#Muslim neighbors|campaign against the Muslims]], and her ensuing victory at [[Battle of Basian|Basian]] is celebrated in the ''Hymns in Honour of the Virgin of Vardzia'' by [[Ioane Shavteli]]. The ''History of Georgia'' also relates how Vardzia escaped the [[Mongol conquests|Mongol invaders]] in the 1290s. The Persian [[Safavid dynasty|Safavid]] chronicler Hasan Bey Rumlu describes Vardzia as a "wonder", "impregnable as the wall of [[Alexander the Great]]", before recounting its sack by the Persians under Shah [[Tahmasp I]] in 1551; a near-contemporary note in the Vardzia Gospel tells of its repatriation from a Persian bazaar. After the arrival of the [[History of Georgia (country)#Ottoman and Persian domination|Ottomans]] in 1578, the monks departed and the site was abandoned.<ref name="GG"/>
==Site== The greater Vardzia area includes also the early eleventh-century church at Zeda Vardzia and the tenth- to twelfth-century rock village and cave churches of Ananauri. The main lower site was carved from the cliff's central [[stratum]] of [[Tufa|tufaceous]] [[breccia]] at an elevation of thirteen hundred metres above sea level. It is divided into an eastern and a western part by the Church of the Dormition. In the eastern part of the complex are seventy-nine separate cave dwellings, in eight tiers and with a total of 242 rooms, including six chapels, "Tamar's Room", a meeting room, reception chamber, pharmacy, and twenty-five wine cellars; 185 wine jars sunk into the floor document the importance of [[viticulture]] to the monastic economy. In the western part, between the bell tower and the main church, are a further forty houses, in thirteen tiers and with a total of 165 rooms, including six chapels, a [[refectory]] with a bakery, other ovens for baking bread, and a [[forge]]. Beyond the bell tower the complex rises to nineteen tiers, with steps leading to a cemetery. Infrastructure includes access tunnels, water facilities, and provision for defence.<ref name="NACH"/><ref name="GG"/><ref name="ICOMOS"/>
==Church of the Dormition== [[File:Vardzia Cave City, Georgia (inside).jpg|thumb|right|200px|View to the [[apse]] and [[Orthodox church (building)#Iconostasis|iconostasis]] or screen decorated with [[icon]]s that separates the [[Orthodox church (building)#Nave|nave]] from the [[Orthodox church (building)#Sanctuary|sanctuary]]]] The Church of the Dormition was the central spiritual and monumental focus of the site. Carved similarly from the rock, its walls reinforced in stone, it measures {{convert|8.2|m|ft}} by {{convert|14.5|m|ft}}, rising to a height of {{convert|9.2|m|ft}}. Both church and [[Orthodox church (building)#Narthex|narthex]] are painted; these paintings are of "crucial significance in the development of the Medieval Georgian mural painting".<ref name="UNESCO"/> Its patron, Rati [[Surameli]], is commemorated in a [[donor portrait]] on the north wall; the accompanying [[Epigraphy|inscription]] reads "Mother of God, accept ... the offering of your servant Rati, ''[[eristavi]]'' of [[Kartli]], who has zealously decorated this holy church to your glory".<ref name="GG"/> On the same north wall are portraits of the royal founders, [[George III of Georgia|Giorgi III]] and [[Tamar of Georgia|Tamar]]; she lacks the ribbon that is the attribute of a married woman and her inscription includes the formula "God grant her a long life", while that of Giorgi does not; this helps date the paintings to between Giorgi's death in 1184 and Tamar's marriage in 1186.<ref name="GG"/> Episodes from the life of Christ occupy the vaults and upper walls in a sequence, starting with the [[Annunciation]], followed by the [[Nativity of Jesus|Nativity]], [[Presentation of Jesus at the Temple|Presentation in the Temple]], [[Baptism of Jesus|Baptism]], [[Transfiguration of Jesus|Transfiguration]], [[Raising of Lazarus]], [[Triumphal entry into Jerusalem|Triumphal Entry into Jerusalem]], [[Last Supper]], [[Foot washing|Washing of the Feet]], [[Crucifixion of Jesus|Crucifixion]], [[Harrowing of Hell]], [[Ascension of Jesus|Ascension]], [[Descent of the Holy Spirit]], and [[Dormition of the Theotokos|Dormition]] (the church is sometimes known as the Church of the [[Assumption of Mary|Assumption]], which corresponds with the [[Great Feasts of the Orthodox Church|Orthodox Feast]] of the Dormition).<ref name="GG"/><ref name="Courtauld"/> At a lower level, more accessible as [[Intercession of saints|intercessors]], are paintings of saints and [[stylites]]. On the rear wall of the [[Orthodox_church_(building)#Sanctuary|sanctuary]], behind the altar, are [[Church Fathers#Greek Fathers|Twelve Church Fathers]]. In the [[Orthodox church (building)#Narthex|narthex]] are scenes of the [[Last Judgment]], [[Bosom of Abraham]], Angels bearing a Medallion with the Cross, and three scenes from the life of [[Saint Stephen]]; other paintings were lost in the 1283 earthquake.<ref name="GG"/> The paintings are not [[Fresco|frescoes]], but executed in ''secco'', and "testify to contacts with the Christian Orient and the [[Byzantine art|Byzantine]] world, but applied using local artistic traditions".<ref name="ICOMOS"/>
==Management== Since 1985 the site has formed part of the Vardzia Historical–Architectural Museum-Reserve, which includes forty-six architectural sites, twelve archaeological sites, and twenty-one sites of monumental art.<ref name="reserve"/><ref name="ICOMOS">{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/archive/2001/whc-01-conf205-inf4e.pdf |title=Evaluations of Cultural Properties by ICOMOS (2001) |pages=18-21 |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=1 May 2012}}</ref> In 1999 Vardzia-[[Khertvisi]] was submitted for inscription on the [[UNESCO]] [[World Heritage List]] as a Cultural Site in accordance with criteria [[World_Heritage_Site#Cultural_criteria|ii, iii, iv, v, and vi]].<ref name="ICOMOS"/> In their evaluation, advisory body [[ICOMOS]] cited [[Göreme]] in [[Cappadocia]] as the closest [[Wiktionary:comparandum|comparandum]] amongst cave monastery sites of international [[Values (heritage)|significance]].<ref name="ICOMOS"/> In 2007 Vardzia-[[Khertvisi]] was resubmitted as a mixed Cultural and Natural Site in accordance also with criterion [[World Heritage Site#Natural criteria|vii]].<ref name="UNESCO"/> From 2012, [[Conservation-restoration|conservation]] of the wall paintings in the Church of the Dormition is to be carried out by the [[Courtauld Institute of Art]] in conjunction with the [[National Agency for Cultural Heritage Preservation of Georgia]] and [[Tbilisi State Academy of Arts]].<ref name="Courtauld">{{cite web |url=http://www.courtauld.ac.uk/news/documents/Vardzia_Courtauld_Georgia_Collaboration.pdf |title=Vardzia: Preserving the Wall Paintings of Georgia |publisher=[[Courtauld Institute of Art]] |accessdate=1 May 2012}}</ref>
